title: What are the definite examples of phenomenology, the one associated with Husserl, on how it could relate to interacting with others? - Quora

response.answer_text: In my reading, the phenomenology of Husserl involves a first-person meditation on first-person mental processes. There is no social interaction involved in Husserl’s phenomenological procedure. Husserl developed no social theory from his phenomenology. This was not his purpose. Yet perhaps we can surmise a social implication from his actual purpose. In my reading, Husserl’s purpose was to save the Subjective Reality from being overwhelmed by a massive Objectivity of Government, Taxes, War, Science, Industry, Public Education, Medicine and so on. There is a sincere scientific inquiry today, regarding whether or not the Self even exists. This is what Husserl feared. Husserl hoped that philosophers would write volume after volume of first-person accounts of first-person mental processes. This would eventually establish a literature of the Subjective. Instead, Husserl did not finish his work, but was interrupted by the rise of the Nazi Party. Husserl was an ethnic Jew, so he lost his job. Martin Heidegger (who was a long time member of the Nazi Party) took his job. There is a Nazi myth that persists in Encyclopedias today — that Heidegger built his philosophy upon Husserl’s phenomenology. But such falsehoods never quote Husserl himself on the topic. Husserl denied that Heidegger built upon his phenomenology. Husserl’s work stopped when Husserl was booted off of his University position because he was an ethnic Jew during the rise of the Nazi Party. Period. There are two social implications here (and thus implications for interacting with others). One is obviously political — involving anti-Semitism. The other is Husserl’s moral purpose — to salvage an awareness of the Cartesian Cogito. It seems that Husserl’s purpose loses ground more and more as time goes on.

for me, H. is always about the appearance of the thing giving the most data for an understanding of what’s human. but, for me it depends on the person observing. i have really good photographer’s eyesight — 20/10 corrected, and i simply see a lot. if i were a doctor and a diagnostician i’d see even more and with a special gravity. if i were a father seeing his daughter, etc… or any special case. but, this is why Heidegger admired Husserl so much — that Husserl wasn’t all ‘mental’ about things. not looking for the soul essence of things can really help you see things in context — not get lost in the possible secret meaning of things and what they might have for you as knowledge. with phenomenology you simply see and respond and file it away. sartre goes on to say that seeing means identifying the human and demands a collective and concerned response to anything human. ( i think that’s how it goes. ) maybe reading sartre’s novels would be an interesting read…?
